ix 1.0 INTRODUCTION The Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan (R-ARCSS), signed on 12th September 2018 in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, mandates the Revitalised Transitional Government of National Unity (R-TGoNU) to initiate and oversee a permanent constitution-making process during the Transitional Period.1 The permanent constitution-making process is expected to be completed not later than twenty-four (24) months following the establishment of the Transitional Period and shall be in place to guide the elections towards the end of the Transition.2 Article 6.7 of the Agreement mandates the Reconstituted Joint Monitoring and Evaluation Commission (RJMEC) to convene a workshop for the Parties to the peace agreement to discuss and agree on the details of conducting the constitution-making process.
It is imperative for the permanent constitution to be created in a calm environment uninhibited by the same difficulties that led to the interim or transitional constitutions.

The Arusha Peace Agreement was signed by 17 parties,44 and contained provisions for the permanent cessation of fighting, the creation of a transitional government, and the eventual creation of a final constitutional text for Burundi.

The conference also declared itself sovereign, put in place a transitional constitution and dissolved the national legislature and executive existing then, replacing them instead with a transitional legislature and a transitional executive.

Its eventual adoption was preceded by the conclusion of agreements, such as the Djibouti Accord and the Kampala Accord, to unite different parties – such as the Alliance for the Reliberation of Somalia and the Transitional Federal Government of Somalia.58 There is an ongoing constitutional review process intended to culminate in the creation of a permanent constitution that will then be the basis of universal adult suffrage elections in 2020.
Under Chapter VI of the R-ARCSS, the RTGoNU is expected to initiate and oversee a Permanent Constitution making-process during the Transitional Period to be completed within 24 months.

The Report highlights the most recent progress on the Pre-Transitional activities carried over after the initial formation of the Revitalised Transitional Government of National Unity (RTGoNU) on 22nd February 2020, as well as the tasks scheduled to be undertaken in the Transitional Period.
Required to be completed one month after the institution of the RTGoNU, the establishment of a Special Fund for Reconstruction (SRF) and its Board (BSRF) (Article 3.2) is long overdue.

With almost a year into the Transitional Period completed, the Report highlights the decided lack of progress on the Pre-Transitional activities carried over after the initial formation of the Revitalised Transitional Government of National Unity (RTGoNU) on 22 February 2020, as well as failure to undertake tasks scheduled during the Transitional Period.
Ten months into the proposed thirty-six months Transitional Period, much remains to be done by the Reconstituted Transitional Government of National Unity (R-TGoNU) to implement the Agreement.

Much remains to be done by the Revitalized Transitional Government of National Unity (RTGoNU) especially considering that less than two years remain in the Transitional Period as it was previously agreed upon.
Under Chapter 6 of the R-ARCSS, the RTGoNU is mandated to initiate and oversee a permanent Constitution-making process which is expected to be completed within 24 months into the Transitional Period.
With only 20 months remaining to the end of the Transitional Period, there is need to ensure that the outstanding tasks of the R-ARCSS are simultaneously implemented.

Under Chapter 6 of the R-ARCSS, the RTGoNU is mandated to initiate and oversee a permanent Constitution-making process, which is expected to be completed within 24 months into the Transitional Period.
Within the timelines of the Agreement, the Transitional Period is expected to end in February 2023, preceded by elections conducted 60 days prior, under a new Permanent Constitution.

It is clear that much effort is required on the part of the RTGoNU and TNL to keep the implementation of the R-ARCSS at a pace which will realise the holding of elections at the end of the Transitional Period.
As per the provision of the R-ARCSS, the JRC was meant to be established no later than three months into the Transitional Period.
b) the National Elections Act 2021 is to be amended within two months upon adoption of the Permanent Constitution to ensure that it conforms to its provisions (Article 1.20.6 of the R-ARCSS).

However, even as the timeline for the implementation of the Revitalised Agreement is fast running out, considerable efforts have been made by RJMEC to emphasise the centrality of the permanent Constitution making process to the conduct of elections at the end of the Transitional Period under the Agreement, as well as for the sustainability of peace in South Sudan.
Moreover, elections are required to be conducted under the provisions of the permanent constitution as per article 1.20.5 of the RARCSS;
The R-ARCSS provides for elections to be held 60 days before the end of the Transitional Period.

The general political and security situation in the Republic of South Sudan continues to offer hope for a successful implementation of the R-ARCSS, underpinned by a commendable show of commitment and cooperation exhibited by all the Parties.

segments.text: This report builds on our continuous and ongoing efforts, to help the people of the Republic of South Sudan in their search for enduring peace, justice and good governance based on the rule of law and constitutionalism.

As the constitutional process moves forward to the preparation of a permanent constitution, however, the process should be more open and transparent, with oversight from, and input by, the people of the State.140 A permanent constitution should be the product of a robust and inclusive dialogue, which protects the rights and interests of all groups in the country.

Democratic Representation In addition to public participation, an important factor for the legitimacy of the constitution and the stability of the system it establishes is democratic representation in the constitutional commission, which may take the lead on drafting;

After nearly two years of intensive consultations, the Constitutional Assembly negotiated a draft which was a representative integration of ideas from ordinary citizens, civil society and political parties represented in and outside of the Constitutional Assembly.66 The South African Constitution therefore broadly represented the collective wisdom of the South African people, arrived at by general agreement.67 Conclusively therefore, the South African Constitution was drafted and adopted by the South African Parliament of 1994, in accordance with guidance provided under the interim Constitution of 1993.

Sudan’s 2005 Interim National Constitution – now suspended – outlined a decentralised and broadly federal structure of government for the country.120 At the time, it also encompassed South Sudan, which subsequently became an independent and sovereign State in its own right.121 Sudan currently has 18 States, each with its own governor and council of ministers.122 Shortly after Sudan attained self-government from colonial rule, the First Sudanese Civil War broke out.

South Africa, Eritrea, and Rwanda are more successful examples of this aspect of the process, whereby a carefully planned program of civic education was conducted to educate the population on the role of a constitution in society generally and their role in constitution making.
RJMEC is equally engaging with numerous South Sudanese civil society actors and organizations working on governance and constitutional development to contribute to the process.
Important issues related to governance such as the reconstitution of the TNLA and completing the Permanent Constitution must be resolved.

The RJMEC is mandated to convene a workshop for the R-ARCSS Parties to agree on the details of the Permanent Constitution-making Process in the fourth month, and its outcome is to form the basis for a legislation to be enacted to govern the Constitution-making process.

The critical outstanding tasks include the unification of forces and their redeployment, the making of the permanent constitution, and the start of the elections process, to pave the way for the holding of free, fair and credible elections.
The Bill promotes prudent, transparent and accountable management of national wealth and resources, the rule of law and constitutional and democratic governance in the Republic of South Sudan.

segments.text: On 1-2 April Hug visited Donetsk and Dnepropetrovsk. He assessed the state of the ceasefire and followed up on steps towards the implementation of the Minsk package - such as the ceasefire and the withdrawal of heavy weaponry. He also visited Donetsk Airport and the residential area nearby of Spartak.
Risk factors remained, with weapons in violation of withdrawal lines; mines, unexploded ordnance and remnants of war present; armed forces and formations precariously positioned close to one another.

Risk factors remained: weapons in violation of withdrawal lines; mines, unexploded ordnance and explosive remnants of war present; armed forces and formations positioned dangerously close to one another.

Factors contributing to the armed violence – the failure of the sides to withdraw weapons, disengage forces and formations, and de-mine – continue. The Mission continued to observe heavy weapons in violation of withdrawal lines: 18 in government-controlled areas and 99 in areas outside of government control. Mines and unexploded ordnance remained in place in many areas, in particular in and around entry-exit checkpoints. On 19 November the SMM noted for the first time three anti-tank mines about 30m north of the road between Pyshchevyk and “DPR”-controlled Verkhnoshyrokivske, less than 2km east of Pyshchevyk.

The SMM continued to observe weapons in violation of agreed withdrawal lines (155 over the two-week period (61 in areas not controlled by the Government)). It also noted large amounts of hardware being routed through government-controlled Kostiantynivka, and convoys of trucks entering and exiting Ukraine via a dirt track where there are no border crossing facilities in a non-government-controlled area of Donetsk region.

The Mission observed 119 weapons in violation of the agreed withdrawal lines (109 in areas not controlled by the Government); and mines and unexploded ordnance, includ- ing over 1,000 freshly-laid anti-tank mines near Veselohorivka.

segments.text: On 13 February, Zannier and Apakan in a joint statement in Kyiv said that the SMM is ready to monitor the ceasefire, and to engage all sides that are entrusted to upholding the implementation of the peace agreements.
The SMM observed a general de-escalation starting from 15 February. Ceasefire violations have been recorded at: Bakhmutka, Debaltseve, Donetsk Airport, Pervomaisk, Shyrokyne, Trokhizbenka, Vrubivka.
The ceasefire in eastern Ukraine is largely holding but there continue to be viola-tions in and around Donetsk airport and Shyrokyne.

On 1-2 April Hug visited Donetsk and Dnepropetrovsk. He assessed the state of the ceasefire and followed up on steps towards the implementation of the Minsk package - such as the ceasefire and the withdrawal of heavy weaponry. He also visited Donetsk Airport and the residential area nearby of Spartak.

The SMM issued its fifth thematic report “Protection of Civilians and their Freedom of Movement in the Donetsk and Luhansk Regions”. Read the report in three languages (English, Ukrainian, Russian) here: www.osce.org/ukraine-smm/156791

The SMM observed and heard continued fighting in the areas in and around “Donetsk People’s Republic” (“DPR”)-controlled Donetsk airport; the area of “DPR”-controlled Horlivka and Debaltseve and in Shyrokyne.

Areas in and around Donetsk airport were the primary focus of fighting. The situation in the Luhansk region remained tense with sporadic violence observed by the SMM in Shchastia, Trokhizbenka, Zolote and Stanytsia Luhanska.
In the Donetsk and Luhansk regions the overall situation along the contact line remained tense.

On 23-25 July Mr. Hug visited Donetsk to support the team after a protest outside the SMM location in Donetsk; and to follow-up on the shelling of Donetsk city centre of 18 July, meeting with interlocutors and media.
On 21 July the SMM observed the planned movement of military equipment by both Ukrainian Armed Forces and “Donetsk People’s Republic”.
The ceasefire largely held for three consecutive weeks. The SMM recorded relatively low levels of ceasefire violations in the Donetsk and Luhansk regions.

The SMM has noted a spike in ceasefire violations in Donetsk region, particularly in the wider areas around Donetsk airport, while the security situation in Luhansk region has remained relatively calm.

In his statement on 13 November the Chief Monitor of the OSCE SMM, Ertugrul Apakan, deplored the recent increase in both gravity and number of ceasefire violations in eastern Ukraine, and urged the sides to honour their commitments under the Minsk agreements.

On 28-29 November the SMM Chief Monitor Ertugrul Apakan travelled to eastern Ukraine and visited Kramatorsk (Donetsk region), Sievierodonetsk and Novoaidar (Luhansk region) as well as a permanent weapons storage site in Luhansk region. Read more here: www.osce.org/ukraine-smm/204981

The SMM has noted numerous ceasefire violations in Donetsk region, particularly in the areas around Donetsk airport. On 24 November alone the SMM registered over 570 explosions only in the Donetsk region. The security situation in Luhansk region has also been volatile.

The OSCE SMM Principal Deputy Chief Monitor Alexander Hug on 6-10 December 2015 visited Donetsk, Horlivka, Debaltseve, Pavlopil, Avdiivka and other representatives of the Joint Centre for Control and Co-ordination, and other interlocutors. in eastern Ukraine, where he met the SMM teams, locations

The security situation has been volatile with areas at and around Donetsk airport sometimes registering no ceasefire violations for several days, while Horlivka has seen a marked increase in violence, including the use of mortars and Multiple Launch Rocket Systems (MLRS). The Pavlopil-Oktiabr-Kominternove triangle, where previously the sides had been repositioning and deploying, now also shows signs of escalation. Luhansk region remains relatively calm.

The SMM issued a new Thematic Report on Access to Justice and the Conflict in Ukraine, highlighting the challenges faced by people residing in both government and non-government-controlled areas in Donetsk and Luhansk regions. Read the report at: www.osce.org/ukraine-smm/212311

Multiple ceasefire violations were observed by the SMM in the Donetsk region, in particular in the Horlivka area, and from 20 January onwards, at and around Donetsk airport and in Debaltseve. Many of the incidents involved proscribed artillery and mortars, underlining that not all weapons of this type have been withdrawn from the contact line. The SMM noted ongoing tension in several places, in particular in the Pavlopil-Oktiabr-Kominternove triangle where the sides had re-positioned closer towards each other.

An escalation of violence in several locations was noted by the OSCE Special Monitoring Mission to Ukraine (SMM), especially around the outskirts of Donetsk city, around Horlivka and between Debaltseve and Svitlodarsk. On 30 January and 2 February the number of ceasefire violations reached more than 1,000.

More than 1,800 explosions were observed by the SMM across the Donetsk region in the last week with ceasefire violations concentrated around Donetsk airport, south-west of Donetsk city, north-east of Donetsk city (Horlivka, Zaitseve and Svitlodarsk), and north-east of Mariupol (Kominternove and Oktiabr).

There were continued violations of the ceasefire by both sides. The OSCE Special Monitoring Mission to Ukraine (SMM) recorded the most violent breaches west of Donetsk city and around Donetsk airport, in and around Horlivka – in particular, in the Svitlodarsk/Debaltseve area – and in areas north- east of Mariupol, around Kominternove. In Luhansk region, the overall security situation remained relatively calm, with daily ceasefire violations numbering in the low double-digits – most of these were attributable to live-fire exercises.

A high level of violence around Svitlodarsk and in areas to the north and west of Donetsk city, in particular around Avdiivka and Yasynuvata, was noted by the OSCE Special Monitoring Mission to Ukraine (SMM) over the past two weeks.

On 17-22 March the OSCE SMM Principal Deputy Chief Monitor Alexander Hug visited eastern Ukraine. Hug patrolled Donetsk and Luhansk regions, met with SMM teams, and conducted meetings with Joint Centre for Control and Co-operation representatives and other relevant interlocutors.

The OSCE Special Monitoring Mission (SMM) to Ukraine observed increased violence, in particular in the Donetsk region. More than half of all ceasefire violations registered in Donetsk region were recorded in the Yasynuvata-Avdiivka area. Significant fighting was also observed in Svitlodarsk, areas north-west of Donetsk city and at Donetsk airport. The SMM also noted a rise in ceasefire violations in southern Donetsk region.

The number of ceasefire violations registered by the Special Monitoring Mission (SMM) in Donetsk region remained high. The use of mortar fire hit a new high with around 970 explosions recorded between 11-17 April. Fighting concentrated around three hotspots: the area between Avdiivka and Yasynuvata, and also Donetsk airport; the northern and western outskirts of Horlivka; and the area south and south-east of Svitlodarsk.
The Yasynuvata-Avdiivka area north of Donetsk city and areas south-east of Svitlodarsk remained hotspots, with areas around Donetsk airport again becoming more tense.

The OSCE Special Monitoring Mission to Ukraine (SMM) observed a significant increase in the number of ceasefire violations in both Donetsk and Luhansk regions. Most violence occurred around Donetsk airport; government-controlled Avdiivka, “DPR”-controlled Yasynuvata; on the road between “DPR”-controlled Debaltseve and government-controlled Svitlodarsk; and in the area around the bridge south of government-controlled Stanytsia Luhanska.

The SMM did, however, note a number of breaches of the ceasefire in areas that had been otherwise relatively calm, such as western Luhansk region and the western outskirts of Horlivka, Berezove and Volnovakha in Donetsk region.

In keeping with the regular pattern of ebbs and flows of violence, the OSCE Special Monitoring Mission to Ukraine (SMM) observed a generally high number of ceasefire violations – mostly around Donetsk airport, the Yasynuvata-Avdiivka area, and on the Svitlodarsk-Debaltseve road. There have been occasional lulls and a notable decrease in the violence observed throughout Donbas from 18 to 21 June.

The OSCE Special Monitoring Mission to Ukraine (SMM) observed a high level of ceasefire violations in Donetsk region with violence concentrated around the usual hotspots: the Avdiivka-Yasynuvata-Donetsk airport triangle; the western and northern outskirts of Horlivka; areas around Shyrokyne and Kominternove; and the Svitlodarsk-Debaltseve road.

The SMM observed that the situation remained tense and volatile in Donetsk region with violence concentrated around the usual hotspots: Avdiivka-Yasynuvata -Donetsk airport triangle; western and northern outskirts of Horlivka; areas around Shyrokyne and Pikuzy (formerly Kominternove); and the Svitlodarsk-Debaltseve road.
While visiting Donetsk and Luhansk regions, Ambassador Apakan called upon the sides to ease people’s suffering in eastern Ukraine. Read more at: www.osce.org/ukraine- smm/261801

The OSCE Special Monitoring Mission (SMM) continued to monitor the security situation, noting that it remained highly volatile, unpredictable and highly tense with occasional flare-ups. The Donetsk airport-Yasynuvata-Avdiivka triangle remained the epicentre of violence. The level of violence in Luhansk region remained relatively low with some isolated spikes in ceasefire violations occurring in Stanytsia Luhanska area and in parts of western Luhansk region.

Learn how the OSCE SMM is monitoring the disengagement foreseen in the Framework Decision of September 2016 with the aim of contributing to a full and sustainable ceasefire in Ukraine at: www.osce.org/ukraine-smm/275521

The security situation along the contact line in eastern Ukraine has seriously deteriorated with the SMM registering over 1,000 ceasefire violations daily with recent spikes over 2,000. Shelling was concentrated in the traditional hotspots of the Donetsk airport-Yasynuvata-Avdiivka area, west and north of Horlivka, on the Debaltseve-Svitlodarsk road, areas east and north-east of Mariupol, and in western Luhansk region.

Following a recent sharp increase in fighting in eastern Ukraine, Ertugrul Apakan, SMM Chief Monitor, called on the sides to exercise maximum restraint and establish a full and sustainable ceasefire. Read more at: www.osce.org/ukraine-smm/280771

Between 19 December 2016 and 8 January 2017 approximately half of all ceasefire violations occurred in areas south-east and east of Svitlodarsk. The remaining ceasefire violations largely took place in four other hotspots: areas east and north-east of Mariupol; the western and northern outskirts of Horlivka; the Avdiivka-Yasynuvata-Donetsk airport triangle; and areas of western Luhansk region.

The security situation in eastern Ukraine continued to be volatile and tense. Although the SMM recorded an increase in the number of ceasefire violations during the week of 9-15 January, the mission observed a decline in violations at all main hotspots the following week.

The situation remained relatively tense and volatile with occasional deterioration in some areas. In the week of 6 to 12 February, the SMM noted a 20% increase in ceasefire violations in areas east and north-east of Mariupol. Similarly, there was a significant number of ceasefire violations in areas south-west of Horlivka.

A spike in fighting around the Avdiivka-Yasynuvata-Donetsk airport area on 24 February was noted and the situation continued to be volatile and tense also in other hotspots. In the week of 27 February to 5 March, the SMM monitored a significant increase in the number of ceasefire violations in the following areas: east and north-east of Mariupol; areas located between Popasna, Pervomaisk and Troitske; the western and northern outskirts of Horlivka.

The vast majority of ceasefire violations occurred in areas south-east and east of Svitlodarsk, areas east and north-east of Mariupol, the Avdiivka-Yasynuvata-Donetsk airport triangle, the western and northern outskirts of Horlivka and in western Luhansk region.

The SMM facilitated and monitored local adherence to the ceasefire to enable repairs to essential infrastructure on both sides of the contact line: for example, pipelines near government-controlled Artema and so-called “LPR”-controlled Zolote-5 in Luhansk region; power controlled Olenivka in Donetsk region. lines near government-controlled Luhanske and non-government

Following the re-commitment to ceasefire to mark “International Children’s Day” on 1 June, and an accompanying one-day lull in violence, both Donetsk and Luhansk regions witnessed upsurges in violence. For example, on 3-4 June, the SMM observed artillery and mortar fire exchanges between the Trudivske neighbourhood Krasnohorivka; and on 5-6 June use of artillery, including multiple-launch rocket systems in the Zholobok-Krymske area of Luhansk region. in Petrovskyi district of Donetsk city and neighbouring

The situation in eastern Ukraine remained tense with the SMM registering an increase in the number of ceasefire violations over the last two weeks. The violence was concentrated around five areas: the Avdiivka-Yasynuvata-Donetsk airport area; the area east of Mariupol; the area south-west, south and south-east of Svitlodarsk; the western, south-western and northern outskirts of Horlivka; and around Popasna-Pervomaisk.

The situation in eastern Ukraine remained tense with the SMM initially registering a slight fall and then a subsequent increase in the level of ceasefire violations over the last two weeks. The violence was concentrated around the Avdiivka-Yasynuvata-Donetsk airport area, areas east and north-east of Mariupol, the area south-west, south and south-east of Svitlodarsk, the western, south-western and northern outskirts of Horlivka, and around Popasna-Pervomaisk.

The security situation in eastern Ukraine has slowly but steadily deteriorated following an initial decrease in the number of ceasefire violations when the sides recommitted to the ceasefire in late August. During the week of 9 to 15 October in the areas between Avdiivka, Yasynuvata and the Donetsk airport area and around Horlivka, the levels of armed violence reached the daily number of ceasefire violations recorded before the recommitment.

The security situation in eastern Ukraine during the last two weeks remained tense with the SMM recording 11,425 ceasefire violations in total along the contact line. The Mission noted escalation in a number of areas, notably in the Avdiivka- Yasynuvata-Donetsk airport area from 30 October to 5 November and in areas east and north-east of Mariupol from 6 to 12 November.

Between 27 November and 10 December, the security situation in eastern Ukraine further deteriorated. The SMM recorded close to 19,700 ceasefire violations in total – a 25% increase on the previous two weeks. The vast majority of recorded ceasefire violations were concentrated in the Avdiivka-Yasynuvata-Donetsk airport area; areas south-west, south, and south-east of Svitlodarsk; the Popasna-Pervomaisk area; areas east and north-east of Mariupol; and the western and northern outskirts of Horlivka.

Between 5 and 18 February, the security situation in eastern Ukraine remained volatile. Periods of relative calm were interrupted by sudden violent flare-ups, in particular in the Svitlodarsk-Debaltseve area, in the west of Luhansk region and in areas east and north-east of Mariupol.

Multiple public gatherings, demonstrations and protests took place on 17 and 18 February throughout Ukraine. One of them, involving approximately 70 participants, resulted in acts of vandalism against a number of buildings in Kyiv associated with the Russian Federation.

Between 22 January and 4 February, the security situation in eastern Ukraine remained tense. In terms of the overall number of ceasefire violations recorded by the OSCE SMM along the contact line, little changed between 19 February and 4 March 2018 compared with the previous two-week reporting period.

On 28 February the sides recommitted to the ceasefire as of 00:01 on 5 March. The Mission, where it has safe unfettered access, will report on the level of compliance, with its findings reflected in SMM daily reports, available in three languages (English, Ukrainian and Russian) on the OSCE website: www.osce.org/ukraine-smm/reports

Between 19 March and 1 April 2018, the security situation in the east of Ukraine remained tense and continued to gradually deteriorate. Overall, the number of ceasefire violations in the two-week reporting period reached almost 10,000 (compared to 4,300 in the previous two weeks). This number includes more than 1,000 ceasefire violations recorded in the three days following a renewed commitment to the ceasefire that took effect at 00:01 (Kyiv time) on 30 March.

Between 16 and 29 April 2018, the SMM recorded almost 8,300 ceasefire violations along the contact line in the east of Ukraine – a ten per cent decrease on the previous two-week reporting period. There was a notable upsurge in violence on 24 and 25 April, during which 30 per cent of the total number of recorded ceasefire violations occurred.

On three occasions (9, 10 and 11-12 October), an SMM long-range unmanned aerial vehicle spotted vehicles, including an anti-aircraft gun and an armoured personnel carrier, entering and exiting Ukraine in the middle of the night via an unpaved road near Manych, in a non- government-controlled area of Donetsk region near the border with the Russian Federation where there are no border crossing facilities.

The SMM continued to observe damage caused by shelling and gunfire in and near pop- ulated areas in both Donetsk and Luhansk regions, including to residential buildings in government-controlled Novoluhanske and Travneve, as well as in non-government- controlled Donetsk city, Dokuchaievsk, Yasynuvata and Holmivskyi.

On 21 April, during the second round of the presidential election, the SMM observed a calm security situation in Kyiv, Kherson, Mykolaiv, Odessa, Lviv, Ivano-Frankivsk, Zakarpattia, Kharkiv, Dnipropetrovsk, Vinnytsia, and Chernivtsi regions, as well as in government-controlled areas of Donetsk and Luhansk regions, including at entry-exit checkpoints.
The SMM continued to observe people applying for passports of the Russian Federation in non-government-controlled areas of Donetsk region and started to observe the same in Luhansk region.

On 17 July, the Trilateral Contact Group, with the participation of representatives of certain areas of Donetsk and Luhansk regions, re-affirmed its full commitment to a com- prehensive, sustainable and unlimited ceasefire to start at 00:01 on 21 July.
The Mission’s freedom of movement was restricted two times in government-controlled areas and 36 times in non-government-controlled areas, mostly in the southern part of Donetsk region.
The Mission’s freedom of movement was restricted 61 times in non-government-controlled areas, mostly in southern Donetsk region, and 10 times in areas controlled by the Government.

On 25 October, in Kyiv, Kharkiv, Odessa and Zaporizhzhia, the SMM observed peaceful gatherings of about 80-150 people (mostly men), expressing messages critical of the recent developments concerning certain areas of Donetsk and Luhansk regions.

On 29 October (outside the reporting period), the SMM saw that disengagement from the Zolote disengagement area had begun. Additional SMM patrols, assisted by static cameras and unmanned aerial vehicles, observed the launch of flares by the Ukrainian Armed Forces and the armed formations, signalling both sides’ readiness to disengage, and subsequently Ukrainian Armed Forces personnel and members of the armed for- mations exiting the disengagement area, together with their weapons.

Between 29 June and 12 July, members of the armed formations continued to deny the SMM passage at checkpoints along official crossing routes in Donetsk and Luhansk re-gions (see Spot Report 36/2020 and Spot Report 37/2020). Overall, the Mission’s free-dom of movement was restricted 27 times (26 times in non-government-controlled areas and once in a government-controlled area). SMM unmanned aerial vehicles were subjected to signal interference on both sides of the contact line on 30 occasions, and were targeted by small-arms fire twice – once near Petrivske and once near Stanytsia Luhanska.

The SMM monitored areas east and south-east of Kherson region and observed no change in the security situation, including at checkpoints near Kalanchak, Chonhar and Chaplynka as well as along the North Crimean Canal and the coast of the Sea of Azov.

The Mission followed up on reports of damage to 21 civilian properties and a working kindergarten, on both sides of the contact line, including in Hranitne and in Donetsk city’s Kuibyshevskyi district, Donetsk region as well as in Zolote-5/Mykhailivka in Luhansk re- gion. Overall since the beginning of 2021, the SMM has confirmed damage to 142 civilian properties and infrastructure objects.

provisions.text: The withdrawal of the heavy weapons as specified above is to start on day 2 of the ceasefire at the latest and to be completed within 14 days.

segments.text: The SMM registered ceasefire violations on both sides of the contact line involving weapons ranging from small arms to heavy artillery including weapons that should have been withdrawn according to the Minsk Addendum.

The SMM observed a marked decrease in violence after the sides renewed their commitment to the ceasefire for the new school year starting from 1 September and generally recorded double-digit numbers of ceasefire viola- tions.

The Special Monitoring Mission to Ukraine (SMM) continued to observe steady number of ceasefire violations on a daily basis with some occasional lulls in fighting after recommitment to ceasefire and withdrawal of weapons agreed at meetings of the Trilateral Contact Group in Minsk on 29 March and 12 April. For example, on 8 April, the SMM recorded about 1,700 ceasefire violations, with only around 650 the following day, and on 10 April the number increased again to approximately 1,200 violations.

Continued violence and potential escalation remain as the sides, at best, only partially adhere to their commitments. The disengagement process remains stalled with no progress made around the Stanytsia Luhanska bridge and an increasing number of ceasefire violations recorded in and around the Zolote disengagement area. Heavy weapons continue to be seen in violation of withdrawal lines, with, for example, the SMM noting 10 multiple launch rocket systems near so-called “LPR”-controlled Khrustalnyi on 6 July, and self-propelled howitzers near government-controlled Novookhtyrka on 8 and 9 July (four and two, respectively).

The security situation in eastern Ukraine has slowly but steadily deteriorated following an initial decrease in the number of ceasefire violations when the sides recommitted to the ceasefire in late August. During the week of 9 to 15 October in the areas between Avdiivka, Yasynuvata and the Donetsk airport area and around Horlivka, the levels of armed violence reached the daily number of ceasefire violations recorded before the recommitment.

With a recommitment to the ceasefire coming into effect on 5 March, the Mission noted a decrease of 82 per cent in the number of ceasefire violations in the first week of the reporting period (5-11 March). The following week, however, saw an increase in violence, with the number of ceasefire violations doubled compared with the previous week.

Between 19 March and 1 April 2018, the security situation in the east of Ukraine remained tense and continued to gradually deteriorate. Overall, the number of ceasefire violations in the two-week reporting period reached almost 10,000 (compared to 4,300 in the previous two weeks). This number includes more than 1,000 ceasefire violations recorded in the three days following a renewed commitment to the ceasefire that took effect at 00:01 (Kyiv time) on 30 March.

Between 9 and 22 July, the SMM noted a deterioration of the security situation in eastern Ukraine. In the second week of the re-commitment to the ceasefire, the Mission recorded an increase in the number of ceasefire violations.
Following the recommitment to the ceasefire on 29 December 2018, during the New Year and Christmas festivities, the Mission noted an initial decrease in the number of ceasefire violations.

Between 25 February and 10 March, the SMM recorded almost 15,700 ceasefire viola-tions (compared with over 23,000 in the previous two-week period). The Mission also observed 90 weapons in violation of the agreed withdrawal lines (62 in areas not con-trolled by the Government).

The SMM recorded over 13,000 ceasefire violations (about 14,700 in the previous two- week period); and observed 270 weapons in violation of the agreed withdrawal lines (218 in areas not controlled by the Government).

The SMM recorded almost 12,000 ceasefire violations (over 13,000 in the previous two- week period); and observed 224 weapons in violation of the agreed withdrawal lines (206 in areas not controlled by the Government).

For the tenth week in a row, the security situation remains relatively calm following addi- tional measures to strengthen the ceasefire, which took effect on 27 July. Between 21 September and 4 October, the SMM recorded 429 ceasefire violations, compared with 120 in the previous two-week period. At 71 days, the Mission marked the longest period after a recommitment to the ceasefire where ceasefire violations did not reach pre- recommitment levels.

provisions.text: Immediate measures to stabilize the situation in the conflict area The sides commit to a full and comprehensive implementation of the ceasefire, strengthened by the implementation of all necessary ceasefire support measures, before the end of the year 2019.

segments.text: Between 5 and 18 April 2021, the SMM recorded 3,828 ceasefire violations, compared with 3,922 in the previous two-week period. Of note, a spike of 1,745 ceasefire viola- tions (more than 1,500 of them assessed as live-fire exercises in non-government- controlled areas of Donetsk region) was recorded on 15 April. This is the highest number of ceasefire violations on a single day since the entry into force of the measures to strengthen the ceasefire on 27 July 2020.

topics.text: Restrictions of deployment of artillery and heavy weapons including distances from civilian populations and infrastructure.

agreements.name: On Peaceful Settlement of Situation in the Eastern Regions of Ukraine

provisions.text: Setting up the 10km buffer zone at the Ukrainian-Russian border and the withdrawal of illegal troops and heavy weaponry.

segments.text: On 1-2 April Hug visited Donetsk and Dnepropetrovsk. He assessed the state of the ceasefire and followed up on steps towards the implementation of the Minsk package - such as the ceasefire and the withdrawal of heavy weaponry. He also visited Donetsk Airport and the residential area nearby of Spartak.
Risk factors remained, with weapons in violation of withdrawal lines; mines, unexploded ordnance and remnants of war present; armed forces and formations precariously positioned close to one another.

Risk factors remained: weapons in violation of withdrawal lines; mines, unexploded ordnance and explosive remnants of war present; armed forces and formations positioned dangerously close to one another.

Factors contributing to the armed violence – the failure of the sides to withdraw weapons, disengage forces and formations, and de-mine – continue. The Mission continued to observe heavy weapons in violation of withdrawal lines: 18 in government-controlled areas and 99 in areas outside of government control. Mines and unexploded ordnance remained in place in many areas, in particular in and around entry-exit checkpoints. On 19 November the SMM noted for the first time three anti-tank mines about 30m north of the road between Pyshchevyk and “DPR”-controlled Verkhnoshyrokivske, less than 2km east of Pyshchevyk.

The SMM continued to observe weapons in violation of agreed withdrawal lines (155 over the two-week period (61 in areas not controlled by the Government)). It also noted large amounts of hardware being routed through government-controlled Kostiantynivka, and convoys of trucks entering and exiting Ukraine via a dirt track where there are no border crossing facilities in a non-government-controlled area of Donetsk region.

The Mission observed 119 weapons in violation of the agreed withdrawal lines (109 in areas not controlled by the Government); and mines and unexploded ordnance, includ- ing over 1,000 freshly-laid anti-tank mines near Veselohorivka.

segments.text: The Chief Monitor of the OSCE SMM to Ukraine, Ambassador Ertugrul Apakan, called upon all sides to exercise maximum restraint in eastern Ukraine. The SMM also called upon all parties to immediately stop the fighting in the east, withdraw heavy weapons and armed units from Donetsk airport and from all adjacent residen-tial areas as agreed in the Minsk documents.
On 21 July the SMM observed the planned movement of military equipment by both Ukrainian Armed Forces and “Donetsk People’s Republic”.

On 29 October (outside the reporting period), the SMM saw that disengagement from the Zolote disengagement area had begun. Additional SMM patrols, assisted by static cameras and unmanned aerial vehicles, observed the launch of flares by the Ukrainian Armed Forces and the armed formations, signalling both sides’ readiness to disengage, and subsequently Ukrainian Armed Forces personnel and members of the armed for- mations exiting the disengagement area, together with their weapons.

On 9 November, it observed Ukrainian Armed Forces personnel and members of the armed formations exiting the Petrivske disengagement area, together with their weap-ons (www.osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-to-ukraine/438458).
flying between positions of the Ukrainian Armed Forces and positions of the armed formations. On one occasion, soldiers of the Ukrainian Armed Forces threatened to shoot down an SMM mini-UAV.

provisions.text: A ban is to be introduced on deployment of heavy weapons and military equipment in the district limited by the towns of Komsomolske, Kumacheve, Novoazovsk, Sakhanka, with OSCE monitoring.

segments.text: The Chief Monitor of the OSCE SMM to Ukraine, Ambassador Ertugrul Apakan, called upon all sides to exercise maximum restraint in eastern Ukraine. The SMM also called upon all parties to immediately stop the fighting in the east, withdraw heavy weapons and armed units from Donetsk airport and from all adjacent residen-tial areas as agreed in the Minsk documents.

On 1-2 April Hug visited Donetsk and Dnepropetrovsk. He assessed the state of the ceasefire and followed up on steps towards the implementation of the Minsk package - such as the ceasefire and the withdrawal of heavy weaponry. He also visited Donetsk Airport and the residential area nearby of Spartak.
The SMM has continued to observe ceasefire violations, including use of heavy weapons, tanks and smaller caliber weapons.
The SMM continued to observe large-calibre weapons, and movement of military trucks with equipment in “DPR”, “LPR”-, and government-controlled areas.

The OSCE Special Monitoring Mission to Ukraine (OSCE SMM) opened Forward Patrol Bases in Horlivka and Debaltseve, allowing monitors to increase their operational scope in areas not controlled by the Government. Learn more: www.osce.org/ukraine-smm/208116; www.osce.org/ukraine-smm/208471.

An escalation of violence in several locations was noted by the OSCE Special Monitoring Mission to Ukraine (SMM), especially around the outskirts of Donetsk city, around Horlivka and between Debaltseve and Svitlodarsk. On 30 January and 2 February the number of ceasefire violations reached more than 1,000.

On 20 May in violation of the Package of Measures for the Implementation of the Minsk Agreements, armed “DPR” members cut the power supply to an SMM repeater device in Donetsk city, thereby incapacitating SMM remote monitoring equipment at “DPR”-controlled Oktiabr mine and in government- controlled Avdiivka.

Weapons proscribed by the Minsk agreements continued to be used in high numbers and the SMM registered an increase in the use of mortars, artillery and multiple launch rocket systems. The SMM continued to observe weapons missing from storage sites as well as the presence of weapons in violation of withdrawal lines.

The OSCE SMM continued to monitor the security situation, registering a high number of ceasefire violations along the contact line in eastern Ukraine. Violations include the use of weapons proscribed by the Minsk agreements, namely mortars, artillery, tanks and multiple launch rocket systems.

The Chief Monitor of the SMM, Ertugrul Apakan, addressed the OSCE Permanent Council in Vienna on 12 May. He emphasized that the safety and security of the SMM’s unarmed civilian monitors – and of the wider civilian population in eastern Ukraine – must be prioritized by the sides to the conflict. See: www.osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-to-ukraine/317031

The recorded use of weapons that should have been withdrawn under the Minsk agreements increased almost four-fold between 31 July and 6 August (547 instances) compared to the week before (137 instances). SMM monitors regularly reported on damage to civilian houses due to shelling.

The SMM’s access remained restricted in multiple locations on both sides of the contact line, in particular in areas outside of government control close to the border with the Russian Federation. At a “DPR”-controlled checkpoint near Verkhnoshyrokivske armed men in military-style clothing pointed a heavy machine-gun at an SMM patrol: www.osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-to-ukraine/352556.

Factors contributing to such violence – namely the sides’ refusal to fully cease fire, withdraw heavy weapons, disengage forces and formations, and de-mine – were evident throughout the reporting period. The Mission observed 310 heavy weapons that should have been withdrawn according to the Minsk agreements; an increased number of ceasefire violations within the Petrivske disengagement area towards the end of the reporting period; and mines and unexploded ordnance in many areas, including in and around entry-exit checkpoints used by civilians.

Mines and unexploded ordnance continued to impede SMM patrols. Members of the armed formations in Luhansk region also continued to restrict SMM access to border areas near the Russian Federation not controlled by the Government. For the ninth consecutive week, SMM unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) continued to be subject to small-arms fire and the recently re-launched long-range SMM UAVs were subject to jamming on a number of occasions. Of particular concern was an incident on 5 April, when a member of an armed formation, with a charged assault rifle, threatened SMM monitoring officers. (See: www.osce.org/special- monitoring-mission-to-ukraine/377194).

The Special Representative of the OSCE Chairperson-in-Office in Ukraine and in the Trilateral Contact Group Martin Sajdik and SMM Chief Monitor Ertugrul Apakan welcomed the recommitment to cease fire on 6 July. But they noted that it needed to be matched by a concrete set of actions to be sustainable including the withdrawal of heavy weapons (www.osce.org/chairmanship/386996).

The SMM continued to observe weapons in violation of agreed withdrawal lines (141 over the two-week period (118 Government)) as well as the close proximity of Armed Forces and armed formations, and the ongoing presence of mines and unexploded ordnance. in areas not controlled by the

By 5 August, the Mission confirmed that 31 civilians had been killed since the start of the year and another 137 had been injured. In addition to threats posed by mines and unexploded ordnance – which the sides are obliged to remove – the Mission continued to face restrictions on its movement, in particular in areas not controlled by the Government in southern Donetsk region and along the Ukraine-Russian Federation border in Luhansk region.

The SMM continued to observe weapons in violation of agreed withdrawal lines (155 over the two-week period (61 in areas not controlled by the Government)). It also noted large amounts of hardware being routed through government-controlled Kostiantynivka, and convoys of trucks entering and exiting Ukraine via a dirt track where there are no border crossing facilities in a non-government-controlled area of Donetsk region.

In addition to the ongoing threats posed by the presence of mines and unexploded ordnance – which the sides have undertaken to remove – the Mission continued to encounter restrictions of its freedom of movement. This was particularly the case at checkpoints in non-government-controlled areas of the southern Donetsk region and in areas near the border with the Russian Federation outside government control.

The Mission recorded 147 weapons in violation of the agreed withdrawal lines (112 in areas not controlled by the Government). It also noted hardware in or close to residential areas, placing civilians in danger. For example, an armoured reconnaissance vehicle was observed about 30-40m from a house near Popasna and five armoured combat vehicles in Luhansk city.

The second week of May saw a significant increase in the use of weapons that should have been withdrawn in accordance with the Minsk agreements (around 1,000 instanc- es). In total, from 6 to 19 May monitors observed 277 weapons in violation of the agreed withdrawal lines (216 in areas not controlled by the Government).

The Mission observed 44 weapons in violation of the agreed withdrawal lines (32 in areas not controlled by the Government). It also noted the presence of weapons and other hardware in residential areas, which puts civilians and their property at risk. For instance, SMM unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) spotted surface-to-air missile systems close to houses in Chernenko and close to a functioning school in Tarasivka; and infantry fighting vehicles in residential areas of Bezimenne and Luhansk city.

Addressing the OSCE Permanent Council in Vienna on 5 September, SMM Chief Monitor Yaşar Halit Çevik noted that the recommitment to the ceasefire was followed by a re-duced number of ceasefire violations and a consequent improvement in the security (https://osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-to-situation ukraine/429290). in eastern Ukraine

The SMM recorded 35 weapons in violation of their respective withdrawal lines, com- pared to 138 in the previous two-week period. The Mission continued to observe the presence of heavy weapons, as well as military and military-type positions and hard- ware, in and near residential areas, including a self-propelled anti-aircraft gun in Ku- rakhove and a tank in Novohryhorivka.

On 13 April, while monitoring adherence to a localized ceasefire to facilitate the operation of the Donetsk Filtration Station, an SMM patrol in Yasynuvata came under fire, with bullets or pieces of shrapnel flying overhead and three rounds from undetermined weapons impacting nearby (see Spot Report 12/2020).

provisions.text: At the same time, artillery systems of more than 100 millimeter caliber are to be moved back from their juxtaposition by the length of their maximum range, in particular:

Within 24 hours after the approval of this memorandum, all lethal weapons more than 100 millimeter caliber are to be moved back from juxtaposition by at least 15 kilometers (with the exception of those indicated below), including from residential areas, which will allow to create a zone from from use of weapons of no less than 30 kilometers in width (the safety zone).

segments.text: From 20 to 26 February, the SMM observed 86 weapons in violation of withdrawal lines. It has not observed any withdrawal of weapons from the security zone, despite repeated recommitments in this regard by the sides, including in February. Unless the sides disengage and withdraw weapons, intense violence remains an ever-present danger. In the week from 27 February to 5 March the use of Minsk-proscribed weapons, namely mortars, tanks, and artillery, increased by 230 per cent as compared with the previous week. including MLRS,

Aggressive restrictions to the SMM’s freedom of movement continued, primarily in non-government-controlled areas. For example on 7 June, an SMM patrol in the Novoazovsk area was physically prevented from moving; seven vehicles without licence plates occupied by armed men surrounded the patrol and kept it blocked for about 20 minutes before ordering it to leave the area (see: www.osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-to-ukraine/322181). In addition, the Mission’s unmanned aerial vehicles were assessed as targeted with small-arms fire on three occasions, two of them in areas not under governmental control. No injuries or damage ensued.

The SMM’s freedom of movement has remained restricted in multiple areas, in particular in border areas close to so-called “DPR”-controlled Novoazovsk, where armed men have systematically prevented the Mission from patrolling for the entire reporting period. Denial of access, in areas not controlled by the Government, has sometimes been accompanied by threats to the SMM with, for example, an armed so-called “DPR” member pointing a rifle at SMM monitors near Kreminets on 7 July.

Factors contributing to the armed violence – the failure of the sides to withdraw weapons, disengage forces and formations, and de-mine – continue. The Mission continued to observe heavy weapons in violation of withdrawal lines: 18 in government-controlled areas and 99 in areas outside of government control. Mines and unexploded ordnance remained in place in many areas, in particular in and around entry-exit checkpoints. On 19 November the SMM noted for the first time three anti-tank mines about 30m north of the road between Pyshchevyk and “DPR”-controlled Verkhnoshyrokivske, less than 2km east of Pyshchevyk.

The SMM’s freedom of movement remained restricted on both sides of the contact line, especially around Travneve, where mines and unexploded ordnance prevented repeated attempts to enter the village, and close to the border areas with the Russian Federation around Siedove (southern Donetsk region), where patrols have been consistently denied access by armed members of the “DPR” since April 2017. The SMM faced impediments in the air as well, with one of its unmanned aerial vehicles being fired upon while in non-government-controlled Dovhe on 27 November.

The Mission did, however, observe localized upsurges in violence, in particular in the Popasna- Pervomaisk area of western Luhansk region. In the first week of the reporting period, almost 90 percent of all explosions caused by weapons that should have been withdrawn according to the Minsk agreements were recorded in this area. The following week, the majority of such explosions were recorded in areas south and south-east of Svitlodarsk, a change possibly due to the fact that the Mission’s night-time monitoring capacity in and around Popasna was compromised during this time.

The OSCE SMM’s freedom of movement remained restricted due to the presence of mines and unexploded ordnance on both sides of the contact line, as well as due to the denial of access by the sides (mainly in areas not controlled by the Government). For instance, on 23 March, small arms were fired near an SMM patrol in Pikuzy and the SMM heard impacts assessed as ricochets of two bullets 5-10m north of its position. On 30 March, three SMM unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) were fired at over non-government-controlled areas.

Between 29 October and 11 November, the SMM recorded over 18,000 ceasefire violations (slightly more than in the previous two-week period) and 89 weapons in violation of the agreed withdrawal lines (58 in areas not controlled by the Government). The SMM observed the continued presence of mines and unexploded ordnance, including recently-laid anti-tank mines near government-controlled Orikhove and an anti-personnel mine near non-government-controlled Verkhnoshyrokivske.

The Mission recorded 147 weapons in violation of the agreed withdrawal lines (112 in areas not controlled by the Government). It also noted hardware in or close to residential areas, placing civilians in danger. For example, an armoured reconnaissance vehicle was observed about 30-40m from a house near Popasna and five armoured combat vehicles in Luhansk city.

In 2018 the SMM observed about 3,800 weapons in violation of withdrawal lines; about six per cent fewer than in 2017. About 60 per cent of such weapons were observed in non- government-controlled areas.

Between 14 and 27 January, the SMM recorded almost 9,500 ceasefire violations (compared with over 6,500 in the previous two-week period) and 170 weapons in viola-tion of the agreed withdrawal lines (53 in areas not controlled by the Government). It also noted hardware in or close to residential areas, placing civilians in danger. For example, it observed three self-propelled howitzers in residential areas in government-controlled Vidrodzhennia and three tanks near residential houses in non-government-controlled Zaichenko. casualties since 1 January 2019 to four (all injured).

The second week of May saw a significant increase in the use of weapons that should have been withdrawn in accordance with the Minsk agreements (around 1,000 instanc- es). In total, from 6 to 19 May monitors observed 277 weapons in violation of the agreed withdrawal lines (216 in areas not controlled by the Government).

The Mission observed 134 weapons in violation of the agreed withdrawal lines (125 in areas not controlled by the Government); and mines and unexploded ordnance, includ-ing 46 anti-tank mines near Shyrokyne, and another 25, approximately 600 metres to the east across the contact line.

Between 15 and 28 July, the SMM recorded over 6,000 ceasefire violations (compared with almost 14,000 in the previous two-week period). Over 75 percent of ceasefire viola-tions were recorded in the first six days of the reporting period, prior to the recommit-ment coming into effect. In the days following the recommitment coming into effect, while most areas remained calm, the level of violence remained high in three areas, including the Popasna-Pervomaisk-Zolote area of Luhansk region. The security situation in the Stanytsia Luhanska disengagement area has remained calm since the Mission noted the beginning of the disengagement of forces and hardware there on 26 June.

The SMM observed 242 weapons in violation of withdrawal lines (170 in nongovernment-controlled areas and 72 in government-controlled areas) as well as mines and unexploded ordnance, including 22 antitank mines about 200m from civilian houses in Vodiane and 72 anti-tank mines within the area of the destroyed Donetsk International airport.

The SMM recorded 111 weapons in violation of their respective withdrawal lines, com- pared to 108 in the previous five-week period: 87 in government-controlled areas and 24 in areas outside government control. The Mission continued to observe military and military-type presence, including in and near residential areas. It spotted, for instance, infantry fighting vehicles in a residential area of Popasna and a probable anti-aircraft gun in a residential area of Verkhnoshyrokivske (formerly Oktiabr).

During the reporting period, the Mission’s freedom of movement was restricted 68 times. Sixty-five instances occurred in areas not controlled by the Government, mostly in southern Donetsk region and at border crossing points in Luhansk region. A number of restrictions occurred at the contact line, along official crossing routes (see Spot Report 2/2020). SMM UAVs were subjected to signal interference on both sides of the contact line on 30 occasions, resulting in the loss of a mid-range UAV inside the Petrivske disengagement area. SMM UAVs were targeted by small- arms fire six times (twice in government-controlled areas and four times in non- government-controlled areas).

• Between 10 and 16 January, the SMM observed increased numbers of heavy weapons violations and beyond withdrawal lines, especially in training areas in non-government-controlled areas of Luhansk region. The SMM recorded ceasefire violations attributable to the use of weapons that should have been withdrawn according to the Minsk agreements. Between 17 and 23 January, the Mission observed an almost threefold decrease of heavy weapons violations and an over fourfold decrease of weapons beyond withdrawal lines. It recorded no ceasefire violations attributable to the use of weapons that should have been withdrawn according to the Minsk agreements.

provisions.text: Withdrawal of heavy weapons by both sides on equal distances in order to create a security zone at least 50 km wide from each other for the artillery systems with caliber greater than 100mm and more, a security zone of 70 km wide for MLRS and 140 km wide for MLRS “Tornado-C”, “Uragan”, “Smerch” and Tactical missile systems “Tochka” (“Tochka U”): - for the Ukrainian troops:

segments.text: The same day in Pisky (near Donetsk airport), four mortar shells landed nearby an SMM patrol while it was approaching an observation point. Less than two hours later, the same patrol, while stationary in Adviivka, came under cross fire including by 152mm artillery that is proscribed under the Minsk agreements. In both cases there were no injuries.

Multiple ceasefire violations were observed by the SMM in the Donetsk region, in particular in the Horlivka area, and from 20 January onwards, at and around Donetsk airport and in Debaltseve. Many of the incidents involved proscribed artillery and mortars, underlining that not all weapons of this type have been withdrawn from the contact line. The SMM noted ongoing tension in several places, in particular in the Pavlopil-Oktiabr-Kominternove triangle where the sides had re-positioned closer towards each other.

The SMM noted risk factors underlying the violence, namely, the proximity of forces and hardware and the presence of proscribed weapons in the security zone. Of note, since 5 April the SMM has observed the presence of a concentration of weapons at an aerodrome in the south-eastern outskirts of so-called “LPR”-controlled Luhansk city, comprising seven multiple launch rocket systems (MLRS), 17 howitzers and seven tanks. In government-controlled areas it noted six MLRS near Dobropillia on 15 April and 18 MLRS in Lyman as well as 12 anti-tank guns near Sievierodonetsk on 17 April. See: www.osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-to-ukraine/312026.

Following the re-commitment to ceasefire to mark “International Children’s Day” on 1 June, and an accompanying one-day lull in violence, both Donetsk and Luhansk regions witnessed upsurges in violence. For example, on 3-4 June, the SMM observed artillery and mortar fire exchanges between the Trudivske neighbourhood Krasnohorivka; and on 5-6 June use of artillery, including multiple-launch rocket systems in the Zholobok-Krymske area of Luhansk region. in Petrovskyi district of Donetsk city and neighbouring

The safety and security of SMM monitors was interfered with on two occasions. On 20 June, as monitors were patrolling close to the so-called “DPR”-controlled Yasynuvata railway station, an armed man pointed an assault rifle at them, then tried to smash the windows of their vehicle and subsequently fired shots at the vehicle as it departed from the scene (see: www.osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-to-ukraine/324391). On 23 June, in government-controlled Zolote, bullets, mortars and grenades were fired approximately 100m from SMM patrol members, with some bullets flying close overhead (see: www.osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-toukraine/325376).

Factors contributing to the armed violence – the failure of the sides to withdraw weapons, disengage forces and formations, and de-mine – continue. The Mission continued to observe heavy weapons in violation of withdrawal lines: 18 in government-controlled areas and 99 in areas outside of government control. Mines and unexploded ordnance remained in place in many areas, in particular in and around entry-exit checkpoints. On 19 November the SMM noted for the first time three anti-tank mines about 30m north of the road between Pyshchevyk and “DPR”-controlled Verkhnoshyrokivske, less than 2km east of Pyshchevyk.

On 28 March, the Mission re-introduced the use of long-range UAVs. With a range of over 160km, the SMM’s long-range UAVs will operate over Donetsk and Luhansk regions equally on both sides of the contact line, including at night when ground patrolling is restricted due to security considerations.

The SMM’s freedom of movement remained restricted due to the presence of mines and unexploded ordnance on both sides of the contact line, as well as due to other restrictions, mostly denial of access, by members of the armed formations (22 times) and by the Ukrainian Armed Forces (12 times). In one incident on 30 May, in a non-government-controlled area near Petrivske, an SMM patrol heard an explosion less than 300m from its location (www.osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-to-ukraine/383014). In another incident on 7 June, in government-controlled Pivdenne, SMM patrol members heard warning shots fired 70-100m from them (www.osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-to-ukraine/383895). In addition, the sides have continued to target SMM unmanned aerial vehicles, through jamming and targeting them with small-arms fire. In one incident on 9 June, an SMM long-range UAV spotted a surface-to-air missile system (9K33 Osa) near non-government-controlled Ukrainske and recorded the contrail of one missile at approximately the same altitude of the UAV and the launching of a second missile passing below the SMM’s UAV.

On three occasions (9, 10 and 11-12 October), an SMM long-range unmanned aerial vehicle spotted vehicles, including an anti-aircraft gun and an armoured personnel carrier, entering and exiting Ukraine in the middle of the night via an unpaved road near Manych, in a non- government-controlled area of Donetsk region near the border with the Russian Federation where there are no border crossing facilities.
The Mission also recorded almost 70 instances in which weapons that should have been withdrawn were used (mostly mortars and artillery in the vicinity of Svitlodarsk and Popasna).

The SMM observed 242 weapons in violation of withdrawal lines (170 in nongovernment-controlled areas and 72 in government-controlled areas) as well as mines and unexploded ordnance, including 22 antitank mines about 200m from civilian houses in Vodiane and 72 anti-tank mines within the area of the destroyed Donetsk International airport.

The SMM continued to observe anti-tank mines and unexploded ordnance, in particular in southern Donetsk region on both sides of the contact line. Specifically, SMM UAVs spotted 350 anti-tank mines south of Pyshchevyk, 250 east of Vodiane, about 65 in east- ern areas of Hnutove, and 365 in areas north and south-east of Pikuzy. The UAVs also spotted 130 anti-tank mines placed near and across the road between Talakivka and Pikuzy.

On both sides of the contact line in Donetsk and Luhansk regions, SMM unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) continued spotting mines, including 4,165 anti-tank mines, about 100 probable anti-personnel mines and three pieces of unexploded ordnance.

provisions.text: Ensure effective monitoring and verification of the ceasefire regime and the withdrawal of heavy weapons by the OSCE from the day 1 of the withdrawal, using all technical equipment necessary, including satellites, drones, radar equipment, etc. 4.

segments.text: The SMM continued to observe large-calibre weapons, and movement of military trucks with equipment in “DPR”, “LPR”-, and government-controlled areas.
The SMM continued to observe weapons and military movements in the security zone or close to it. The SMM also observed heavy weapons inside agreed withdrawal lines.

On 20 May in violation of the Package of Measures for the Implementation of the Minsk Agreements, armed “DPR” members cut the power supply to an SMM repeater device in Donetsk city, thereby incapacitating SMM remote monitoring equipment at “DPR”-controlled Oktiabr mine and in government- controlled Avdiivka.

Weapons proscribed by the Minsk agreements continued to be used in high numbers and the SMM registered an increase in the use of mortars, artillery and multiple launch rocket systems. The SMM continued to observe weapons missing from storage sites as well as the presence of weapons in violation of withdrawal lines.

The OSCE SMM continued to monitor the security situation, registering a high number of ceasefire violations along the contact line in eastern Ukraine. Violations include the use of weapons proscribed by the Minsk agreements, namely mortars, artillery, tanks and multiple launch rocket systems.

Continued attacks on technical monitoring equipment, namely unmanned aerial vehicles and cameras, also impacted the Mission’s ability to monitor. On 10 August, the Mission’s newly installed thermal camera at the Donetsk Filtration Station near Yasynuvata was destroyed by small-arms fire. The SMM Chief Monitor condemned the incident (see: www.osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-to-ukraine/335046).

Factors contributing to such violence – namely the sides’ refusal to fully cease fire, withdraw heavy weapons, disengage forces and formations, and de-mine – were evident throughout the reporting period. The Mission observed 310 heavy weapons that should have been withdrawn according to the Minsk agreements; an increased number of ceasefire violations within the Petrivske disengagement area towards the end of the reporting period; and mines and unexploded ordnance in many areas, including in and around entry-exit checkpoints used by civilians.

Factors contributing to the armed violence – the failure of the sides to withdraw weapons, disengage forces and formations, and de-mine – continue. The Mission continued to observe heavy weapons in violation of withdrawal lines: 18 in government-controlled areas and 99 in areas outside of government control. Mines and unexploded ordnance remained in place in many areas, in particular in and around entry-exit checkpoints. On 19 November the SMM noted for the first time three anti-tank mines about 30m north of the road between Pyshchevyk and “DPR”-controlled Verkhnoshyrokivske, less than 2km east of Pyshchevyk.

Mines and unexploded ordnance continued to impede SMM patrols. Members of the armed formations in Luhansk region also continued to restrict SMM access to border areas near the Russian Federation not controlled by the Government. For the ninth consecutive week, SMM unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) continued to be subject to small-arms fire and the recently re-launched long-range SMM UAVs were subject to jamming on a number of occasions. Of particular concern was an incident on 5 April, when a member of an armed formation, with a charged assault rifle, threatened SMM monitoring officers. (See: www.osce.org/special- monitoring-mission-to-ukraine/377194).

The Mission’s aerial monitoring was subject to restrictions as well. On 15 June, over non-governmentcontrolled Betmanove, an SMM long-range unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) was fired at by a surface-to-air missile system and an anti-aircraft gun. (Spot Report: https://www.osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-toukraine/384642). On 18 June, small-arms fire was directed at an SMM mini-UAV near Petrivske. On nine occasions, control over SMM UAVs was temporarily lost, most probably due to electronic jamming, on both sides of the contact line.

The SMM continued to observe weapons in violation of agreed withdrawal lines (141 over the two-week period (118 Government)) as well as the close proximity of Armed Forces and armed formations, and the ongoing presence of mines and unexploded ordnance. in areas not controlled by the

In the reporting period, the Mission continued to experience various forms of restrictions affecting its monitoring, including 77 active restrictions on its monitoring officers on the ground, 54 in areas not controlled by the Government, routinely so in areas close to the border with the Russian Federation; three instances in which small-arms fire was registered in the vicinity of monitoring officers, assessed as aimed at SMM UAVs, resulting in the UAVs having to be recalled; 25 instances in which SMM UAVs experienced signal interference affecting their ability to operate to varying degrees; and, the loss of one long-range UAV, which had just prior to its loss spotted a surface-to-air missile system and had experienced signal interference.

Targeting of SMM unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) has continued. Small-arms fire was directed towards SMM UAVs on five occasions. One mini-UAV was hit by a bullet. Al- most on a daily basis, SMM UAVs were subjected to signal interference (assessed as jamming). A long-range UAV was lost on 19 April close to the contact line in Donetsk region. It is the third such aircraft to be lost in six months.

In addition to the presence of mines and unexploded ordnance, the Mission’s freedom of movement was actively restricted by the armed formations 43 times and by the Ukrainian Armed Forces three times. SMM mini- and mid-range unmanned aerial vehi- cles (UAV) continued to experience signal interference, assessed as jamming, while fly- ing over government- and non-government-controlled areas of Donetsk region. In one case, the Mission lost contact with a mid-range UAV shortly after the aircraft had experi- enced signal interference near non-government-controlled Azov. Small-arms fire was twice directed at an SMM mini-UAV sent to locate the lost aircraft.

The Mission observed 44 weapons in violation of the agreed withdrawal lines (32 in areas not controlled by the Government). It also noted the presence of weapons and other hardware in residential areas, which puts civilians and their property at risk. For instance, SMM unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) spotted surface-to-air missile systems close to houses in Chernenko and close to a functioning school in Tarasivka; and infantry fighting vehicles in residential areas of Bezimenne and Luhansk city.

SMM unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) were targeted by small-arms fire on four occa- sions, and subjected to signal interference, assessed as jamming, on an almost daily basis. Twenty two of 25 mini-UAV flights conducted to search for a long-range UAV lost on 27 June near Zaichenko experienced GPS signal interference. One SMM mini-UAV was lost while flying over Khreshchatytske.

SMM unmanned aerial vehicles were targeted by small-arms fire on four occasions, and subjected to signal interference, assessed as jamming, on 55 occasions. In Stanytsia Luhanska, where the SMM has monitored the process of disengagement of forces and hardware, the Mission continued to observe a calm security situation. It not-ed further dismantling of fortifications and continued preparation for the repair of the broken section of the bridge there, with engineering inspections and assessments, de-mining, vegetation clearance and road widening taking place.

On 29 October (outside the reporting period), the SMM saw that disengagement from the Zolote disengagement area had begun. Additional SMM patrols, assisted by static cameras and unmanned aerial vehicles, observed the launch of flares by the Ukrainian Armed Forces and the armed formations, signalling both sides’ readiness to disengage, and subsequently Ukrainian Armed Forces personnel and members of the armed for- mations exiting the disengagement area, together with their weapons.

On 15 May, explosions occurred within approximately 20 metres of SMM patrol mem-bers, who were at the time monitoring adherence to a localized ceasefire and con-ducting an announced unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) flight close to Berezivske (see Spot Report 24/2020).

The SMM continued monitoring the security situation in and around the three pilot dis- engagement areas, recording no ceasefire violations, but noting again the regular pres- ence of people within, or close to, former military and military-type positions inside the areas near Zolote and Petrivske. The Mission’s ability to access and monitor the latter area remains hindered due to the destruction of the SMM camera system in Petrivske by gunfire on 2 June, as well as a lack of demining to provide access to the Bohdanivka- Viktorivka-Petrivske road.

SMM unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) were targeted 13 times by small-arms fire, all but three in non-government-controlled areas. The Mission’s UAVs experienced signal inter- ference assessed as caused by probable jamming or jamming on 136 occasions on both sides of the contact line, including 12 cases when long-range UAVs were targeted, caus- ing four flight cancellations, one inability to take off and one emergency landing of long- range UAVs (see Spot Reports 6/2021 and 8/2021). One mini-UAV was also lost due to jamming. Over the last two months, 82 per cent of SMM long-range UAV flights have encountered GPS signal interference. The Mission had to disable its camera system at the Oktiabr mine near Donetsk city on 19 April to avoid interference with its monitoring, after two men in camouflage-clothing had mounted two cameras on the SMM’s camera mast and the tower on which the mast is emplaced (see Spot Report 10/2021).

segments.text: The SMM continued to observe damage caused by shelling and gunfire in and near pop- ulated areas in both Donetsk and Luhansk regions, including to residential buildings in government-controlled Novoluhanske and Travneve, as well as in non-government- controlled Donetsk city, Dokuchaievsk, Yasynuvata and Holmivskyi.

Placing civilians and their property at risk, weapons remain in or close to residential areas, including in this reporting period, three towed mortars or howitzers in Para- skoviivka and multiple launch rocket systems in Luhansk city.

The Mission observed 44 weapons in violation of the agreed withdrawal lines (32 in areas not controlled by the Government). It also noted the presence of weapons and other hardware in residential areas, which puts civilians and their property at risk. For instance, SMM unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) spotted surface-to-air missile systems close to houses in Chernenko and close to a functioning school in Tarasivka; and infantry fighting vehicles in residential areas of Bezimenne and Luhansk city.
The SMM observed damage caused by small-arms fire and shelling to civilian property and infrastructure in numerous locations along the contact line.

The SMM observed damage caused by small-arms fire and shelling to civilian property and infrastructure in numerous locations along the contact line, including to a day clinic, a power station, residential homes and functioning schools. One school in Zolote, which was hit by gunfire, has sustained damage 11 times since the start of the year.

The SMM recorded 111 weapons in violation of their respective withdrawal lines, com- pared to 108 in the previous five-week period: 87 in government-controlled areas and 24 in areas outside government control. The Mission continued to observe military and military-type presence, including in and near residential areas. It spotted, for instance, infantry fighting vehicles in a residential area of Popasna and a probable anti-aircraft gun in a residential area of Verkhnoshyrokivske (formerly Oktiabr).

The leaderships of the Ukrainian Armed Forces and CADLR armed formations will make public statements about the issuance of the orders listing all the above measures and confirm that these ceasefire orders comply with such measures.
